body_content.explanation: a document, article, etc. that is available before it is officially published:
examples: The following is a preprint of an article for the magazine, due to be published in May.
He was attending a meeting of physicists when one pulled out the pre-print for a forthcoming paper by Jones.

body_content.explanation: to print a letter or information on a form, label, etc. so that someone does not have to write it or fill it out themselves:
examples: Enrolment forms are preprinted for most students before enrolment each autumn.
The bank's "Switchers Kit" includes pre-printed letters to help customers change direct debts and standing orders.

body_content.explanation: to make a printed copy of a document, article, etc. available before it is officially published:
examples: Pre-internet physics had a tradition of preprinting articles.

body_content.explanation: to print something before a particular event or time:
examples: They produce a minimal number of shirts and wait to see the result of the game, but they would not say how many shirts are preprinted.
